clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Early Pelvic Binder Use in Emergency Management of Suspected Pelvic Trauma: a Retrospective Cohort Study
clinical_study.official_title: Division of Traumatic and General Surgery, Department of Surgery, Tri-Service General Hospital, National Defense Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators aimed to evaluate the effect of early pelvic binder use in emergency management of suspected pelvic trauma, compared with the conventional stepwise approach.

detailed_description.textblock:
There is currently no universal consensus on all aspects of management of pelvic injuries.
Among patients with multiple injuries because of blunt trauma, 5%-16% sustain injuries to the pelvic ring, resulting in a mortality rate of 11%-54% primarily due to hemorrhagic shock. In theory, the reduction and stabilization of the pelvic ring can decrease bleeding from the fracture site, as reduction of pelvic volume has been shown to reduce the extent of hemorrhage from such injuries.The application of a pelvic binder has become part of the emergency care of all trauma patients with suspected pelvic fractures, in both the pre-hospital environment and emergency department (ED). The present study aimed to assess the effectiveness of the early use of pelvic binders to treat patients with a suspected high risk of pelvic bleeding from blunt force pelvic fractures.

intervention.description: The requirement of angioembolization can be predicted by the presence of intravenous contrast extravasation (ICE) on computed tomography (CT)

study_pop.textblock: We enrolled trauma patients with initial stabilization using a pelvic binder for suspecting pelvic injury. Inclusion criteria were traumatic injury requiring a trauma team and at least one of the following: loss of consciousness or Glasgow coma score (GCS) < 13; systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg; falling from ≥6 m; injury to multiple vital organs; and suspected pelvic injury. Various parameters, including gender, age, mechanism of injury, GCS, mortality, hospital stay, initial vital sign, revised trauma score, injury severity score, and outcome, were assessed and compared with historical controls.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Traumatic injury requiring a trauma team and at least one of the following: loss of consciousness or Glasgow coma score (GCS) < 13; systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg; falling from ≥6 m; injury to multiple vital organs; and suspected pelvic injury. -
Exclusion Criteria:
- Not meet the criteria and loss follow up (transfer to other hospital or data not available) -
